english: If only ~ happens (even once), then that alone is enough; さえ adds an “even/only” minimum condition. Often implies “I don’t need anything else if just that happens.”
japanese_example: <ruby>一度<rt>いちど</rt></ruby>でも<ruby>連絡<rt>れんらく</rt></ruby>が<ruby>来<rt>き</rt></ruby>さえしたら、もう<ruby>十分<rt>じゅうぶん</rt></ruby>だ。
english_example: If I get even a single message, that alone is enough.

english: Even one; even a single ~ (emphasizes that the minimum of one is sufficient or notable). Often used with さえ/だけ/なら, etc.
japanese_example: <ruby>一<rt>ひと</rt></ruby>つでも<ruby>証拠<rt>しょうこ</rt></ruby>があれば、<ruby>話<rt>はなし</rt></ruby>は<ruby>進<rt>すす</rt></ruby>む。
english_example: If there’s even a single piece of evidence, things will move forward.

english: After that; as for the rest. Often marks what follows once the first condition is met.
japanese_example: <ruby>準備<rt>じゅんび</rt></ruby>が<ruby>終<rt>お</rt></ruby>わったら、あとは<ruby>待<rt>ま</rt></ruby>つだけだ。
english_example: Once the preparations are done, all that’s left is to wait.

english: To show oneself; to appear (one’s presence becomes visible). Often used when someone finally comes or makes an appearance.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>会議<rt>かいぎ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>一度<rt>いちど</rt></ruby>も<ruby>姿<rt>すがた</rt></ruby>を<ruby>見<rt>み</rt></ruby>せなかった。
english_example: He didn’t show up to the meeting even once.

english: Even just ~; if only ~ (emphasizes that the minimum alone is meaningful). Often expresses relief or strong feeling from a small condition.
japanese_example: そう<ruby>思<rt>おも</rt></ruby>えるだけでも、どんなに<ruby>救<rt>すく</rt></ruby>われるか。
english_example: Even just being able to think that—how much it would help me.

english: How very ~; to what extent ~ (strong emphasis on degree). Common in emotional statements like どんなに嬉しいか.
japanese_example: あなたに<ruby>会<rt>あ</rt></ruby>えたら、どんなに<ruby>嬉<rt>うれ</rt></ruby>しいか。
english_example: If I could see you, how happy I would be.

english: Not only ~; it’s not all ~ (counters the idea that something is exclusively one thing). Past form: 〜ばかりではなかった.
japanese_example: <ruby>人生<rt>じんせい</rt></ruby>は<ruby>楽<rt>たの</rt></ruby>しいことばかりではない。
english_example: Life isn’t all fun things.

english: End of the school year (academic year-end). Often used around finals, closing ceremonies, and report cards.
japanese_example: <ruby>学年末<rt>がくねんまつ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>試験<rt>しけん</rt></ruby>が<ruby>続<rt>つづ</rt></ruby>いて<ruby>忙<rt>いそが</rt></ruby>しい。
english_example: At the end of the school year, exams continue and it gets busy.

english: One-on-one; one versus one. Used for lessons, talks, matches, etc.
japanese_example: <ruby>先生<rt>せんせい</rt></ruby>と<ruby>一対一<rt>いったいいち</rt></ruby>で<ruby>練習<rt>れんしゅう</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: I practiced one-on-one with the teacher.

english: Showdown; face-off; confrontation (often dramatic or competitive).
japanese_example: <ruby>決勝<rt>けっしょう</rt></ruby>で<ruby>宿敵<rt>しゅくてき</rt></ruby>との<ruby>対決<rt>たいけつ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>実現<rt>じつげん</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: A showdown with our archrival happened in the final.

english: Shadow; shade; also a presence/trace depending on context. Often contrasts with light or suggests something hidden.
japanese_example: <ruby>月明<rt>つきあ</rt></ruby>かりで<ruby>木<rt>き</rt></ruby>の<ruby>影<rt>かげ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>長<rt>なが</rt></ruby>く<ruby>伸<rt>の</rt></ruby>びていた。
english_example: In the moonlight, the tree’s shadow stretched long.

english: A former likeness/semblance (usually in the fixed phrase 見る影もない: not even a trace of what it used to be).
japanese_example: <ruby>昔<rt>むかし</rt></ruby>の<ruby>元気<rt>げんき</rt></ruby>な<ruby>姿<rt>すがた</rt></ruby>は<ruby>見<rt>み</rt></ruby>る<ruby>影<rt>かげ</rt></ruby>もない。
english_example: There’s not even a trace of the energetic person they used to be.

english: To decline; to weaken; to wane (strength, health, power, ability). Intransitive.
japanese_example: <ruby>体力<rt>たいりょく</rt></ruby>が<ruby>衰<rt>おとろ</rt></ruby>えると、<ruby>疲<rt>つか</rt></ruby>れやすくなる。
english_example: When your stamina declines, you get tired more easily.

english: Although ~; but (literary/formal contrast). States a fact then contrasts with an unexpected result or limitation.
japanese_example: <ruby>謝<rt>あやま</rt></ruby>ったものの、<ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>はまだ<ruby>納得<rt>なっとく</rt></ruby>していない。
english_example: Although I apologized, he still isn’t convinced.

english: Cunning; sly; crafty (often negative, suggesting scheming). Typically used in more formal writing.
japanese_example: <ruby>狡猾<rt>こうかつ</rt></ruby>な<ruby>手口<rt>てぐち</rt></ruby>に<ruby>皆<rt>みな</rt></ruby>がだまされた。
english_example: Everyone was deceived by the cunning trick.

english: Power; authority (especially political/organizational power). Often used with 握る, 持つ, 行使する.
japanese_example: <ruby>権力<rt>けんりょく</rt></ruby>を<ruby>持<rt>も</rt></ruby>つ<ruby>人<rt>ひと</rt></ruby>ほど<ruby>責任<rt>せきにん</rt></ruby>が<ruby>重<rt>おも</rt></ruby>い。
english_example: The more power someone has, the heavier their responsibility is.

english: To take back; to regain (lost time, trust, health, territory, etc.).
japanese_example: <ruby>失<rt>うしな</rt></ruby>った<ruby>信頼<rt>しんらい</rt></ruby>を<ruby>取<rt>と</rt></ruby>り<ruby>戻<rt>もど</rt></ruby>すのは<ruby>難<rt>むずか</rt></ruby>しい。
english_example: It’s difficult to regain lost trust.

english: Volitional of 取り戻す: “let’s regain it / I’ll take it back.” Expresses intention or a proposal.
japanese_example: <ruby>自信<rt>じしん</rt></ruby>を<ruby>取<rt>と</rt></ruby>り<ruby>戻<rt>もど</rt></ruby>そう。
english_example: Let’s regain our confidence.

english: Obsession; tenacity; persistent fixation (often intense, sometimes negative). Common: 執念深い.
japanese_example: <ruby>執念<rt>しゅうねん</rt></ruby>だけで<ruby>最後<rt>さいご</rt></ruby>までやり<ruby>抜<rt>ぬ</rt></ruby>いた。
english_example: I pushed through to the end on sheer tenacity.

english: To burn (something); also to kindle/ignite emotions (e.g., passion, fighting spirit, obsession). Transitive.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>復讐心<rt>ふくしゅうしん</rt></ruby>を<ruby>燃<rt>も</rt></ruby>やしていた。
english_example: He was burning with a desire for revenge.

english: The second time; the second occurrence. Used for repeating an event or attempt.
japanese_example: <ruby>二度目<rt>にどめ</rt></ruby>はもっと<ruby>慎重<rt>しんちょう</rt></ruby>にやった。
english_example: The second time, I did it more carefully.

english: Barely; narrowly; just barely managed to (set adverbial expression). The も is part of the fixed phrase, not “also.”
japanese_example: <ruby>辛<rt>から</rt></ruby>くも<ruby>試験<rt>しけん</rt></ruby>に<ruby>合格<rt>ごうかく</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: I barely passed the exam.

english: To escape; to evade; to avoid (danger, responsibility, control). Often used with 〜から: 〜から逃れる.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>追跡<rt>ついせき</rt></ruby>を<ruby>逃<rt>のが</rt></ruby>れて<ruby>路地<rt>ろじ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>入<rt>はい</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: He evaded pursuit and slipped into an alley.

english: A close call; by a hair’s breadth (literally “crisis, one hair”). Often used with で or の: 危機一髪で助かる.
japanese_example: <ruby>危機一髪<rt>ききいっぱつ</rt></ruby>で<ruby>事故<rt>じこ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>免<rt>まぬが</rt></ruby>れた。
english_example: I narrowly avoided an accident.

english: To elapse; to pass (time). Often written in kana in set forms like たった (e.g., たった三日).
japanese_example: <ruby>一<rt>いち</rt></ruby><ruby>年<rt>ねん</rt></ruby>が<ruby>経<rt>た</rt></ruby>っても、まだ<ruby>覚<rt>おぼ</rt></ruby>えている。
english_example: Even after a year has passed, I still remember it.

english: Even now; still (often with a nuance that something remains unresolved or unexpectedly continues). Frequently used with negative or ongoing states.
japanese_example: その<ruby>理由<rt>りゆう</rt></ruby>は、いまだに<ruby>分<rt>わ</rt></ruby>からない。
english_example: Even now, I still don’t know the reason.

english: Even now; still (more neutral than いまだに, often simply stating continuation without implying an unresolved issue).
japanese_example: いまでもその<ruby>歌<rt>うた</rt></ruby>を<ruby>聞<rt>き</rt></ruby>くと<ruby>思<rt>おも</rt></ruby>い<ruby>出<rt>だ</rt></ruby>す。
english_example: Even now, when I hear that song, I remember.

english: Night sweats (sweat while sleeping). Often used with かく: 寝汗をかく.
japanese_example: <ruby>暑<rt>あつ</rt></ruby>くて<ruby>寝汗<rt>ねあせ</rt></ruby>をかいた。
english_example: It was hot, and I broke out in night sweats.

english: Soaked through; drenched (adverb/na-adj-like). Used for clothes, hair, body, etc.
japanese_example: <ruby>雨<rt>あめ</rt></ruby>で<ruby>服<rt>ふく</rt></ruby>がびっしょりになった。
english_example: My clothes got soaked through in the rain.
